Blog.post: I called Registration Services. If your GPA for the year is 3.410 or higher, you are considered a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar, or just Stone Scholar, which means you are - more or less - in the top third of the class (33% to 30%). If your GPA is 3.8 or higher, then you are a James Kent Scholar, or Kent Scholar, which means you are in the top 1-3% of the class. As the distribution of grades varies year to year, the percentage ranking can't be determined precisely. Registration Services said that it will be posted to the transcript eventually but may not be posted prior to interviews, and thus students can calculate their own GPA and put it on their resumes. I should further mention that grades are weighted per the number of credit hours.

I've been recently reading a lot about Bill Clinton's presidency and I am increasingly more impressed with the strong President that he was and the amazing legacy that he has left us. I am mostly impressed with his excellent track record on the war on terrorism, where even though he had little indication that there was a terror movement afoot, especially with Al Qaida, he continued to act bravely and forcefully and saved our country from so much destruction and heartache. There was the first attack on the World Trade Center where President Clinton bravely spoke about "bringing the terrorists to justice." I think he even went so far as to indict Osama bin Laden, for which we are all eternally grateful. There was the attack in Yemen on the Americans, the attack on the building in Saudi Arabia, the bombing of the two American embassies in 98. After finding out that these acts were perpetrated by Al Qaida, Bill Clinton bravely sent some planes and dropped several bombs on the terrorist camps. We should all be forever grateful that those bombs probably postponed September 11th for an extra couple months. Although a harder response to these terrorist attacks would have certainly helped us avoid the September 11th tragedy, we would probably have had to act unilaterally, and would have injured the human rights of the terrorists. North Korea is another situation where we are forever in debt to the Clinton Presidency. During his administration he brokered an excellent deal with the North Koreans to protect America's national security. Though the cost of the deal was high--several billion dollars--he successfully fought off the threat of a North Korean nuclear threat until the end of his presidency. Taking a harder stand with the North Koreans before they developed enriched Uranium would, of course, probably been more effective, but it would have certainly hurt the feelings of the international community. Good thing President Clinton avoided that. He was fortunate to choose a running mate, then Senator Al Gore, that would go on to invent the internet, which ended up inflating the economy and providing prosperity to so many Americans. These policy stances, coupled with my great respect for Mr. Clinton's moral integrity make me proud to have lived during such an excellent era of our country's history. Thanks Willy!

Sorry I didn't reply to the post below - I was in Texas getting a car (which is another story altogether). I echo what Steve said - don't try to fake it. My impression is that a lot of the interview is about making a personality connection - will this person fit in with the culture at our firm. You shouldn't forget the typical tricks, though: make sure to make good (but not too much) eye contact, be bright and cheerfull (but not bubbly or scatterbrained), don't have anything on your resume you don't feel comfortable talking about for a couple of minutes, sit up straight, have immaculate grooming, sound intelligent (but don't put on airs) and don't be afraid. Recruiters seem like wild animals - they can sense fear from a mile away. The most important thing that I learned from the whole interview process last year was this: Never fly in from Tokyo the day before EIP.
